Title: Prove that any two consecutive terms of the Fibonacci sequence are relatively prime
Content:
Prove that any two consecutive terms of the Fibonacci sequence are relatively prime. My attempt: We have $f_1 = 1, f_2 = 1, f_3 = 2, \dots$, so obviously $\gcd(f_1, f_2) = 1$. Suppose that $\gcd(f_n, f_{n+1}) = 1$; we will show that $\gcd(f_{n+1}, f_{n+2}) = 1$.
Consider $\gcd(f_{n+1}, f_{n+2}) = \gcd(f_{n+1}, f_{n+1} + f_n)$
because $f_{n+2} = f_{n+1} + f_n.$ Then $\gcd(f_{n+1}, f_{n+1} + f_n) = \gcd(f_{n+1}, f_{n}) = 1$ (gcd property). Hence, $\gcd(f_n, f_{n+1}) = 1$ for all $n > 0$. Am I on the right track? Any feedback would be greatly appreciated. Thanks,
AcceptedAnswer:
Congratulations, you have solved it.
You have used the fact that $\gcd(a+b,b)=\gcd(a,b)$

The Fibonacci sequence is defined by $f_2 = 1$,
For every integer $n \geq 1$, $f_{n+2} = f_{n+1} + f_n$.
Problem: 
Prove that any two consecutive terms of the Fibonacci sequence are relatively prime.
